subject: Ethics
title: Mining Ethics and Indigenous Lands
description: A quick, practical guide to Mining Ethics and Indigenous Lands.

hook.text: In 2020, Rio Tinto blew up a 46,000-year-old Aboriginal sacred site in Australia to mine iron ore.

buildup.text: Mining companies often target land rich in mineralsâ€”land that's also home to Indigenous communities.

discovery.text: Free, prior, and informed consent (FPIC) requires companies to get Indigenous approval before mining.

twist.text: In practice, FPIC is often a checkbox exercise. Communities face pressure, bribes, or legal loopholes.

climax.text: A sacred mountain can't be priced. But mining companies assign dollar values to everything, including culture.

punchline.text: They mined ore. They destroyed 46,000 years of history.

quiz.question: What does FPIC (Free, Prior, and Informed Consent) require?
options: Mining companies must get Indigenous communities' approval before extracting resources on their land
Governments must approve all mining operations regardless of location
Companies must pay a flat fee to mine on any land
